title: Order of operations plus advanced thoughts
Without a try catch block, undefined functions will throw errors and stop execution:

inline_content.Text: Without a try catch block, undefined functions will throw errors and stop execution:

title:
undefinedFunction("This will not get executed");
console.log("I will never run because of the uncaught error!");

content_resolved.code:
undefinedFunction("This will not get executed");
console.log("I will never run because of the uncaught error!");

title: Will throw an error and not run the second line:

inline_content.Text: Will throw an error and not run the second line:

title: // Uncaught ReferenceError: undefinedFunction is not defined

content_resolved.code: // Uncaught ReferenceError: undefinedFunction is not defined

title: You need a try catch block, similar to other languages, to ensure you catch that error so code can continue to execute:

inline_content.Text: You need a try catch block, similar to other languages, to ensure you catch that error so code can continue to execute:

title: Now, we’ve caught the error and can be sure that our code is going to execute

inline_content.Text: Now, we’ve caught the error and can be sure that our code is going to execute

title: What if an error occurs in our catch block!?

inline_content.Text: What if an error occurs in our catch block!?

title: We won’t process the rest of our catch block, and execution will halt except for the finally block.

inline_content.Text: We won’t process the rest of our catch block, and execution will halt except for the finally block.

title:
// The code-block has finished
// Uncaught ReferenceError: otherUndefinedFunction is not defined(…)

content_resolved.code:
// The code-block has finished
// Uncaught ReferenceError: otherUndefinedFunction is not defined(…)

title: You could always nest your try catch blocks.. but you shouldn’t because that will get extremely messy..

inline_content.Text: You could always nest your try catch blocks.. but you shouldn’t because that will get extremely messy..

title: Will catch all errors from the previous example and log the following:

inline_content.Text: Will catch all errors from the previous example and log the following:

title: So, how can we catch all errors!? For undefined variables and functions: you can’t.

inline_content.Text: So, how can we catch all errors!? For undefined variables and functions: you can’t.

title: Also, you shouldn’t wrap every variable and function in a try/catch block, because these are simple examples that will only ever occur once until you fix them. However, for objects, functions and other variables that you know exist, but you don’t know whether their properties or sub-processes or side-effects will exist, or you expect some error states in some circumstances, you should abstract your error handling in some sort of manner. Here is a very basic example and implementation.

inline_content.Text: Also, you shouldn’t wrap every variable and function in a try/catch block, because these are simple examples that will only ever occur once until you fix them. However, for objects, functions and other variables that you know exist, but you don’t know whether their properties or sub-processes or side-effects will exist, or you expect some error states in some circumstances, you should abstract your error handling in some sort of manner. Here is a very basic example and implementation.

title: Without a protected way to call untrusted or exception throwing methods:

inline_content.Text: Without a protected way to call untrusted or exception throwing methods:

title: And with protection:

We catch errors and still process all the expected code, though with a somewhat different syntax. Either way will work, but as you build more advanced applications you will want to start thinking about ways to abstract your error handling.
